SoccerAPI
  • API
  • View page source

API

What follows is a table of the important terms used in this document.

Key

Meaning

Variabiles

Class instance attributes set in the method

Parameters

Parameters passed to methods

The main SoccerAPI module is used for object retrieval, while the classes in the Obj dir are used to scrape & collected individual object data.

Main module

class soccerapi.soccerapi.SoccerAPI(config: dict = {})

The main object.

Variables:

  • db – PostgreSQL database initalization.

  • visualize – Visualize object initalization.

  • db – Scouting object initalization.

  • app – app data configuration.

Vartype:

PostgreSQL

Vartype:

Visualize

Vartype:

Scouting

Example:

Import the soccerapi.soccerapi module, then:

>>> config = {"fapi_host" : "API-FOOTBALL HOST", "fapi_key" : "API-FOOTBALL API KEY"}
>>> api = soccerapi.soccerapi.SoccerAPI(config)
>>> haaland = api.db.get("players", "82172")
>>> stat = haaland.statistic("shots")

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

config (dict) –

This object has a few values and defaults:

  • debug (int): if set to 1 print errors out to the console. If set to 0 it will not. Defaults to 0.

  • fapi_host (str): the hostname used to make requests to API-Football.

  • fapi_key (str): API-Football API Key used for authentication.

  • rate_limit_call_interval (int): rate limit interval in seconds.

    Purpose

    Help avoiding rate limiting FBRef puts in place that prevents data scraping. Too many requests to FBRef can trigger a 24 hour IP Block.

    Recommended value

    60

  • rate_limit_max_calls (int): number of rate limited calls Soccer API can make over the time set by rate_limit_call_interval.

    Purpose

    Helps avoid rate limiting FBRef puts in place that prevents data scraping.

    Recommended value

    5

Example:

config = {
    'debug': 1,
    'fapi_host': 'API-FOOTBALL HOST',
    'fapi_key': 'API KEY',
    'rate_limit_call_interval': 60,
    'rate_limit_max_calls': 5,
}

export_csv(objects, filename='soccer_api_objects.csv')

Export objects to a CSV file.

Parameters:

  • objects (list[Any]) – a list of objects.

  • filename (str) – the output file name. Defaults to soccer_api_objects.csv.

import_csv(path) → list

Import data from a CSV file into an object.

Parameters:

path (str) – the input file name.

Returns:

a list of objects.

Return type:

list[Any]

import_object(path: str) → Any

Import a JSON object.

Parameters:

path (str) – the name of the JSON file.

Returns:

an object from the database.

Return type:

Any

Lib

class soccerapi.lib.postgres.PostgreSQL(app: dict)

The main database object.

Variables:

  • app (dict) – app data configuration. This value is usually passed from the main SoccerAPI object.

  • schema – a class containing data in the form of dictionaries

  • has_connection (int) – tells if database connection is possible. If one or more of the connection parameters are missing this value is set to 0, otherwise it is set to 1.

  • connection_params – PostgreSQL connection settings.

  • cache – cache data.

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

app (dict) – see previous description.

search(table_name: str, query: dict) → list[Any]

Find and return objects.

Parameters:

  • table_name (str) – database table to search on. possible values are players, teams or leagues.

  • query (dict[str]) –

    key-value pair for the ID type to be searched.

    Examples:

    >>> api.db.search(table_name=players, {'player_id': '12345'})
>>> api.db.search(table_name=players, {'fapi_player_id': '12345'})
>>> api.db.search(table_name=players, {'tm_player_id': '12345'})
>>> api.db.search(table_name=players, {'fbref_player_id' : '12345'})

Returns:

a list of objects that the search yields.

Return type:

list[Any]

class soccerapi.lib.visualize.Visualize

The Visualize object. This class is designed to take in Soccer API objects and a series of parameters and generate visualizations.

plot_statistics(objs: list[Player | Team], stats_names: list[str], params: dict | None = None)

Generate and export a scatter plot for a series of Players or Teams over a given season and set of statistics.

Parameters:

  • object (list[str]) – the Players or Teams to plot on the scatter plot.

  • object – statistics to define the X, Y and (optional) Z axis of the scatter plot.

  • params (dict) –

    params dictionary to define the scatter plot customization.

    • title (str): title to be displayed on the visualization. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • description (str): description of signature displayed below the title.

    • signature (str): signature included at the bottom of the visualization.

    • filename (str): file name. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • stats (list[str]): names of the statistics to be used as columns on the radar chart. If not included, default statistics will be used.

    • years (list[str]): which year to plot the statistics of. Use 1 year to plot statistics from a single season. Use 2 years to plot the evolution of a statistic. If not included, the most recent season will be used as default.

    • color (str): color of the points on the scatter plot.

    • use_images (bool): use object logos of images instead of points on the scatter plot.

    • highlight (dict): dictionary describing which points should be highlighted.

      • objects (list[Player|Team]): highlight a list of given objects.

      • color (str*): color of the highlights points.

      • min (bool): highlight the minimum point.

      • max (bool): highlight the maximum point.

      • median (bool): highlight the median point.

      • kmeans (int): Perform kmeans clustering over the scatter plot using a given (k) number of groups.

      • top_n (int): highlight the top n points.

      • top_n_stat (dict): dictionary describing how to highlight the top n of a given statistic.

        • n (int): the top n to highlight.

        • stat (str): statistic used to calculate the top n.

      • top_quartile (bool): highlight all points in the top quartile.

    • label_highlights (bool): include a label (object name) of the objects highlighted.

    • label_all (bool): label (object name) of for all objects.

    • x_label (str): label used along the x axis. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • y_label (str): label used along the y axis. If not set, a default will be generated.

radar(object: Player | Team, params: dict)

Generate and export a radar chart for a player or team detailing a series of their statistics.

Parameters:

  • object (( Player | Team )) – the Player or Team to build a radar chart around.

  • params (dict) –

    params dictionary to define the radar chart customization.

    • title (str): title to be displayed on the visualization. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • description (str): description of signature displayed below the title.

    • signature (str): signature included at the bottom of the visualization.

    • filename (str): file name. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • columns (list[str]): names of the statistics to be used as columns on the radar chart. If not included, default statistics will be used.

set_styling(params: dict)

Change the color scheme and font defaults for your visualizations.

Parameters:

params (dict) –

dictionary describing the color scheme and font.

  • primary_color (str): hex code for the primary color (background color).

  • secondary_color (str): hex code for the secondary color (lines and plot color).

  • tertiary_color (str): hex code for the tertiary color (text color).

  • highlight_color (str): hex code for the highlight color (highlights).

  • font (str): font family for text.

shot_map(player: Player, params: dict)

Generate and export a shot map for a player over a season.

Parameters:

  • object (Player) – the Player or Team to build a shot map of.

  • params (dict) –

    params dictionary to define the shot map customization.

    • title (str): title to be displayed on the visualization. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • description (str): description of signature displayed below the title.

    • signature (str): signature included at the bottom of the visualization.

    • filename (str): file name. If not set, a default will be generated.

venn_diagram(sets: dict, params: dict)

Generate and export a venn diagram chart given two or three sets.

Parameters:

  • sets (dict) – dictionary holding sets to be diagrammed, where the key is the label and the value is the set (list[str]).

  • params (dict) –

    params dictionary to define the radar chart customization.

    • title (str): title to be displayed on the visualization. If not set, a default will be generated.

    • description (str): description of signature displayed below the title.

    • signature (str): signature included at the bottom of the visualization.

    • filename (str): file name. If not set, a default will be generated.

class soccerapi.lib.scouting.Scouting

The Scouting object. This class is provides a series of methods which can be used as tools for scouting players.

cheaper_better_younger(player: Player, players_to_scout: list[Player], stat: str) → dict

Using a Player object, a list of Players to scout and a statistic this method performs a ‘Cheaper, Younger, Better’ styled scouting analysis across that list of Players to scout.

Parameters:

  • player (Player) – the player you are comparing against.

  • players_to_scout (list[Player]) – the players you are scouting.

  • stat (str) – the statistic name you are using to compare these players.

Returns:

returns a dictionary containing the results from the cheaper, younger, better analysis.

Return type:

dict

same_position(player: Player, players_to_scount: Player) → bool

Compares two Player objects and returns true if they play the same position.

Parameters:

  • player (Player) – the player you are comparing against.

  • players_to_scount (Player) – the player you are scouting.

Returns:

returns True if the Players play the same position, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

top_10_by_stat(players: list[Player], stat: str, year: str | None = None) → list[Player]

Scout a list of players and return (in order) the top 10 players for a given stat.

Parameters:

  • player (Player) – the players you are scouting.

  • stat (str) – the statistic name you are using to compare these players.

  • year (Optional[str]) – the year the statistic is from. If this parameter is not set, get the current year.

Returns:

returns a list of the top 10 players by a given stat

Return type:

list[Player]

Obj

class soccerapi.obj.player.Player(player_data: dict, db)

The Player object.

Variables:

  • table – the object type. This value cannot be changed and is fixed to player.

  • first_name (str) – player’s first name.

  • last_name (str) – player’s last name.

  • id (str) – player’s Soccer API ID.

  • tm_id (str) – player’s Transfermarkt ID.

  • fapi_id (str) – player’s API-Football ID.

  • understat_id (str) – player’s Understat ID.

  • db (Any) – a database instance.

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

  • player_data (dict) – an object containing the player’s data as strings

  • db (Any) – a database instance.

analyze_shots(shots) → dict[Statistic]

Get the analysis of a Player’s Understat shooting data.

Returns:

a dictionary of Statistic Objects. In case of an error

Return type:

dict[Statistic]

country() → str

Get the country the Player is from.

Variables:

player_country – a country code.

Returns:

a country code.

Return type:

str

current_team() → Team

Get the current team of the Player.

Variables:

team – the player’s team.

Returns:

the team.

Return type:

Team

export()

Export the Player object as a JSON file.

Note

The output filename is in the format player_{self.id}.json.

fbref_image() → str

Get a URL of the Player’s FBRef image.

Returns:

a URL

Return type:

str

image() → str

Get a URL to the Player’s API-Football image.

Returns:

a URL

Return type:

str

import_data(data: dict[str])

Populate Player object’s data based on a Player JSON file.

Parameters:

data (dict[str]) – JSON representation of the Player object.

Variables:

  • fapi_profile

  • player_country

  • team

  • stats_cache

market_value(year: str | None = None) → int

Get the Player’s Transfermarkt Market Value for a given year.

Parameters:

year (Optional[str]) – the year to be selected. If this parameter is not set, get the current year.

Return type:

int

name() → str

Get the name of the Player.

Returns:

the first and last names.

Return type:

str

positions() → list[str]

Get a list of positions the player is known to play.

Returns:

A list of positions in the form of two letter abbreviations.

Return type:

list[str]

profile() → dict | None

Return the API-Football profile of the Player.

Variables:

fapi_profile

Returns:

the API-Football profile or None in case the response is empty.

Return type:

dict | None

scouting_data() → dict[Statistic] | int

Get the Player’s FBRef scouting profile.

Returns:

an dictionary of of Statistic objects or 0 in case of an error.

Return type:

dict[Statistic] | int

short_name() → str

Get the short name of the Player.

Returns:

the first initial and last names.

Return type:

str

shots_over_season() → list

Get the raw Player’s Understat shooting data over a season.

Returns:

a list of data, or an empty list in case of error.

Return type:

list

statistic(stat, year: str | None = None) → Statistic

Get the Player’s FBRef statistics for a given year and statistic.

Parameters:

  • stat (str) – internal or display name of a statistic.

  • year (Optional[str]) – desired year for the statistics. See the statistic method for more information.

Returns:

a Statistic object.

Return type:

Statistic

statistics(year=None) → dict[Statistic]

Returns the Player’s FBRef Statistics for a given year.

Parameters:

year (Optional[str]) – desired year for the statistics. If not set get the previous year if the current month is between January and June, or the current year otherwise.

Returns:

a hash of Statistic objects

Return type:

dict[Statistic]

to_json() → dict

Get a JSON representation of the Player object.

Return type:

dict

class soccerapi.obj.team.Team(team_data, db)

The Team object.

Variables:

  • id (str) – Team’s Soccer API ID.

  • fbref_id (str) – Teams’s FBRef ID.

  • tm_id (str) – Team’s Transfermarkt ID.

  • fapi_id (str) – Team’s API-Football ID

  • understat_id (str) – teams’s Understat ID.

  • db (PostgreSQL) – PostgreSQL database initalization object.

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

  • team_data

  • db (PostgreSQL) – PostgreSQL database initalization object.

country() → str

Get the country the Team is from.

Returns:

a country code.

Return type:

str

export()

Export the Team object as a JSON file.

Note

The output filename is in the format team_{self.id}.json.

fixture(date: str = None) → Fixture | None

Get a Team’s Fixture for a given date.

Parameters:

date (str) – the date to be selected.

Returns:

a Fixture object, or None in case of error.

Return type:

Fixture | None

Important

In contrast to the fixtures method, the date parameter is required here!

fixtures(year: str | None = None) → list[Fixture] | list

Get a list of Team’s Fixtures for a given year.

Parameters:

year (Optional[str]) – the year to be selected. If this parameter is not set, get the current year.

Returns:

a list of Fixture, or an empty list in case of error.

Return type:

list[Fixture] | list

Important

Gets info from the previous year if the current month is between January and June, or the current year otherwise.

import_data(data: dict[str])

Populate Team object data based on a Team JSON file.

Parameters:

data (dict[str]) – JSON representation of the Team object.

Variables:

  • fapi_profile

  • stats_cache

  • opps_stats_cache

leagues() → list[League]

Returns the Leagues a team is competing in currently.

Returns:

a list of Leagues, or an uninitialized list if the response is empty.

Return type:

list[‘League’]

Important

Gets info from the previous year if the current month is between January and June, or the current year otherwise.

class soccerapi.obj.league.League(league_data, db)

The soccer League object.

Variables:

  • table (str) – the object type. This value cannot be changed and is fixed to leagues.

  • id (str) – League’s Soccer API ID.

  • country (str) – League’s country.

  • tm_id (str) – Leagues’s Transfermarkt ID.

  • fapi_id (str) – League’s API-Football ID.

  • understat_id (str) – league’s Understat ID.

  • fbref_stat_detail_level (str) – level of Statistic detail FBRef provides for this League object.

  • understat_id – Leagues’s Understat ID.

  • db (PostgreSQL) – a database instance.

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

  • league_data – an object containing the League’s data as strings.

  • db (PostgreSQL) – a database instance.

export()

Export the League object as a JSON file.

Note

The output filename is in the format league_{self.id}.json.

fixture_list(year: str | None = None) → list[Fixture]

Get a list of League’s Fixtures for a given year.

Parameters:

year (Optional[str]) – the year to be selected. If this parameter is not set, get the current value.

Returns:

a list of Fixture, or an empty list in case of error.

Return type:

list[Fixture] | list

fixtures(date: str | None = None) → list[Fixture]

Get a list of League’s Fixtures for a given date.

Parameters:

date (Optional[str]) – the date to be selected. If this parameter is not set, get the current local timezone timestamp. Defaults to None.

Returns:

a list of Fixture, or an empty list in case of error.

Return type:

list[Fixture] | list

data (dict[str]) – JSON representation of the League object.

Variables:

  • fapi_profile

Get a JSON representation of the Player object.

dict

class soccerapi.obj.statistic.Statistic(stat_data: dict)

Statistics object.

Variables:

  • key (str) – internal name for a Statistic object.

  • value (float) – numeric value of the Statistic object.

  • percentile (float) – percentile representation of a Statistic’s value.

  • name (str) – display name for a Statistic object.

Create a new instance.

Parameters:

stat_data (dict) – The data to be populated into a Statistic object.

to_json() → dict

Get a JSON representation of the Statistic object.

Return type:

dict

class soccerapi.obj.fixture.Fixture(match_data, db)

The Fixture object.

Variables:

  • id (str) – API-Football Fixture ID.

  • fixture-details (dict) – API-Football Fixture description.

  • home_goals (int) – goals scored by the home team.

  • away_goals (int) – goals scored by the away team.

  • score_history (dict) – history of goals scored in match.

  • league (League) – League the Fixture is from.

  • home_team (Team) – home Team in Fixture.

  • away_team (Team) – away Team in Fixture.

  • db (PostgreSQL) – a database instance.

away_starting_xi() → list[Player]

Get the away Team’s starting XI.

Returns:

a list of the away team’s starting xi players, or an empty list in case of errors.

Return type:

list[Player]

away_team_sheet() → list[Player]

Get the away Team’s entire team sheet.

Returns:

a list of the aways team’s players on their team sheet, or an empty list in case of errors.

Return type:

list[Player]

export()

Export the Fixture object as a JSON file.

Note

The output filename is in the format ficture_{self.id}.json.

home_starting_xi() → list[Player]

Get the home Team’s starting XI.

Returns:

a list of home team’s starting xi players, or an empty list in case of errors.

Return type:

list[Player]

home_team_sheet() → list[Player]

Get the home Team’s entire team sheet.

Returns:

a list of the home team’s players on their team sheet, or an empty list in case of errors.

Return type:

list[Player]

statistics(player: Player | None = None) → list[Statistic]

Get the API-Football statistics from a Fixture for both teams or a given player.

Parameters:

player (Optional[Player]) – Player object you want the statistics of.

Returns:

a hash of Statistic objects.

Return type:

dict[Statistic]

to_json() → dict

Get a JSON representation of the Fixture object.

Return type:

dict
